thread.title: Woodward nonprofit makes room indoors for those experiencing homelessness ahead of arctic blast
thread.title_full: Woodward nonprofit makes room indoors for those experiencing homelessness ahead of arctic blast

title: Woodward nonprofit makes room indoors for those experiencing homelessness ahead of arctic blast
text:
Woodward nonprofit makes room indoors for those experiencing homelessness ahead of arctic blast
Leaders in Woodward said they are prepared to spend up to six full days below freezing.
Leaders in Woodward said they are prepared to spend up to six full days below freezing.
Leaders in Woodward said they are prepared to spend up to six full days below freezing.
As Oklahoma prepares for an arctic blast that hasn't been felt in years, people who help those experiencing homelessness stay safe are making room indoors.
>>
Check live radar | KOCO weather page | Get KOCO on the go
Leaders in Woodward said they are prepared to spend up to six full days below freezing. Just a few minutes outside can be dangerous in these temperatures, which is why a local day shelter is working around the clock.
"We will keep it open 24 hours until the arctic blast is through," said Shanna Gonser, the director of operations at the Day Center.
| MORE | TIMELINE: Snow expected to move into Oklahoma overnight, causing possible slick spots
As subzero temperatures loom, the Day Center scrambled to extend its hours of operation to keep the unhoused safe and warm.
"There is nowhere for them to get out of the elements. We have a homeless shelter here in Woodward. but it only houses eight people," Gonser said.
The shelter typically sees 10 people a day, but during Monday's storm, that number doubled.
"That’s a lot of people that we have in our little building," Gonser said. "This part of our facility is literally 1,250 square feet."
The Woodward County Office of Emergency Management expects wind chills to fall to 20 degrees on Sunday and Monday, making for dangerous conditions for anyone outside for too long.
"Someone could freeze to death, unfortunately, and we don’t want to see that," Gonser said.
But the nonprofit said Woodward is stepping up.
"We have some volunteers coming in to help us work overnight. We have community members bringing in meals and blankets," Gonser said.
